entry.title: 《纽约时报》最后：“特朗普漫无边际的演讲强化了年龄问题”
entry.content:
彼得·贝克 (Peter Baker) 和迪伦·弗里德曼 (Dylan Freedman) 为《纽约时报》进行报道，但玛吉·哈伯曼 (Maggie Haberman) 的共同署名明显缺席：

前总统唐纳德·J·特朗普生动地讲述了他与副总统卡马拉·哈里斯进行的高潮辩论中观众是如何站在他一边的。只不过没有观众。辩论在空荡荡的大厅里进行。正如特朗普所说，没有人“发疯” ，因为没人在场。

当然，任何人都可能记错。但这场辩论发生在一周前，是一个相当令人难忘的时刻。这并不是特朗普最近唯一一次表现出困惑、健忘、语无伦次或脱离现实的情况。事实上，这种情况现在经常发生，甚至不再引起太多关注。

他胡言乱语，他重复自己，他从一个想法漫游到另一个想法——有些想法难以理解，有些尚未完成，有些实际上是奇幻的。他提出的古怪主张似乎完全是凭空捏造的。他离题了一些关于高尔夫、鲨鱼和他自己“美丽”身体的离奇话题。在佐治亚州度过了一天后，他享受了“在路易斯安那州度过的美好一天” 。他表示担心朝鲜“试图杀死我”，而他可能指的是伊朗。直到上个月，特朗普退出竞选五周后，他的讲话仍然像是在与拜登总统竞选一样。

迟到总比不到好，但如果是乔·拜登在一场没有观众的辩论中胡言乱语“观众发疯了”，《纽约时报》第二天就会对此进行报道，而不是一个月后。

我不认为唐纳德·特朗普的关系是正确的。但他显然已经因为痴呆症而丧失了仅有的一点理智， 就像他父亲一样。在他 2017 年至 2021 年的任期内，迹象很明显：

他的第二任白宫幕僚长约翰·F·凯利 (John F. Kelly) 深信特朗普先生心理不平衡，因此买了一本由 27 名心理健康专家撰写的名为《唐纳德·特朗普的危险案例》的书，试图了解他的心理状况。老板更好。事实上，凯利先生开始将特朗普先生的白宫称为“疯狂镇”。

当然，《泰晤士报》必须对这个故事进行两面性的阐述，他们找到了这样做的人：

特朗普前政治顾问萨姆·农伯格表示，他仍然与几乎每天见到他的人交谈，没有听说有人对这位前总统的年龄表示任何担忧。 “我真的没有看到任何重大差异，”他说。 “我就是不明白。”

在罗伯特·穆勒 (Robert Mueller) 调查最激烈的时候，农伯格曾在六次有线电视新闻节目中醉醺醺地出现。那个人说，特朗普今天脑子肯定没问题。

如果你已经有一段时间没有看过特朗普讲话了——因为你和任何理智的选民一样，都在“去他妈的那个家伙”——你应该看看《纽约时报》为这篇文章精选的视频片段。就像我说的，我不认为这家伙曾经有过良好的关系，但很明显他今天的状态严重下滑。

我对哈里斯竞选团队的建议是，他们应该反复将特朗普描述为“80岁的老人”，并迫使特朗普的代理人纠正他们说他“只有”78岁。

★

entry.title: 两名俄罗斯 YouTube 用户发布视频拆箱所谓的 M4 MacBook Pro 基本型号
entry.content:
Joe Rossignol，MacRumors 撰稿：

俄罗斯频道 Romancev768 今天在 YouTube Shorts 上分享了可能是下一代 MacBook Pro 的最新视频，就在一天前，另一个俄罗斯频道分享了类似的视频。该剪辑显示了一个 14 英寸 MacBook Pro 的盒子，显然配置了 M4 芯片，具有 10 核 CPU 和 10 核 GPU、16GB RAM、512GB 存储、三个 Thunderbolt 4 端口和一个 Space Black结束。 [...]

这些泄漏的来源尚不清楚。上周，“ShrimpApplePro”声称，至少一台未发布的 14 英寸 MacBook Pro 显然正在 Facebook 私人群组中出售。在周日 X 上的后续帖子中，泄密者声称他在网上看到某人显然在宣传出售 200 台未发布的 14 英寸 MacBook Pro 设备，这让他相信这次泄密源自仓库。目前尚不清楚这些细节是否准确，但整个情况显然非常粗略。

包装盒艺术与去年的 M3 MacBook Pro 完全相同，这有点奇怪，但我倾向于认为它们是真实的。最好的猜测是，有人从中国偷了 200 个这样的东西，其中部分或全部最后到了俄罗斯？如果发生这种情况，我们不会对苹果表示同情——如果你在独裁统治下组装你的产品，这样的事情就一定会发生。有点令人惊讶的是，iPhone 并没有出现这种情况，因为 iPhone 会在发布前一个月吸引更多的关注和价值。 iPhone 上没有发生这种情况，这可能表明苹果为 iPhone 提供了比 MacBook Pro 更高的安全性。

entry.title: 法官在 Epic 诉 Google 的最终裁决中让 Google 屈服
entry.content:
肖恩·霍利斯特 (Sean Hollister) 为 The Verge 撰文：

谷歌的 Android 应用商店是一种非法垄断——现在它必须改变。今天，法官詹姆斯·多纳托 (James Donato) 对Epic 诉谷歌一案做出了最终裁决，命令谷歌在整整三年内开放 Google Play 应用商店以供竞争。谷歌将不得不在Google Play 内分发竞争对手的第三方应用商店，并且必须让竞争对手的第三方应用商店访问 Google Play 应用程序的完整目录，除非开发者单独选择退出。

这些是Epic 最大的要求，如果不立即暂停或阻止上诉，它们可能会永远改变 Android 应用市场。而这些并不是 Epic 今天赢得的全部。从 2024 年 11 月 1 日开始到 2027 年 11 月 1 日结束，Google 还必须：

  • 停止对 Google Play 商店上分发的应用程序要求 Google Play 结算（陪审团发现 Google 非法将其支付系统与其应用商店绑定）
  • 让 Android 开发者告诉用户在 Play 商店内进行支付的其他方式
  • 让 Android 开发者链接到在 Play 商店之外下载应用程序的方法
  • 让 Android 开发者为应用程序设定自己的价格，而无需考虑 Play Billing

如果这项裁决在上诉中维持不变，这对谷歌来说是真正的损失，而不是象征性的损失。

更新：关于上面第一段中的内容，即竞争对手的应用程序商店可以访问 Play 商店中的所有应用程序，除非开发人员选择退出，我最初很困惑这是如何运作的。我应该先读一下禁令。它指出：

在三年内，Google 将允许第三方 Android 应用商店访问 Google Play 商店的应用程序目录，以便他们可以向用户提供 Play 商店应用程序。对于仅在 Google Play 商店中提供的应用程序（即不能通过第三方 Android 应用商店独立提供的应用程序），Google 将允许用户按照与任何其他应用程序商店相同的条款通过 Google Play 商店完成应用程序的下载。直接通过 Google Play 商店下载。 Google 可能会保留与此类下载相关的所有收入。谷歌将为开发者提供一种机制，允许他们选择不包含在任何特定第三方 Android 应用商店的目录访问中。自该命令发布之日起，谷歌将有最多八个月的时间来实施遵守该规定所需的技术，三年期限将在该技术完全发挥作用后开始。

这句话远没有霍利斯特的描述让我相信的那么激进。 Donato 法官的要求是，对于第三方应用商店中未提供的任何应用和游戏，有效地传递到实际的 Play 商店列表。因此，如果您在 Brand X 应用商店中搜索“FooApp”，但 FooApp 在 Brand X 商店中不可用，则 Brand X 的商店应用程序可以让您从 Play 商店安装和下载 FooApp。但这算作常规的 Play 商店安装。这只是鼓励第三方商店的用户首先搜索这些商店的一种方式，尽管绝大多数应用程序可能只会保留在 Play 商店中。

★

《泰坦尼克号》中有一句台词，任何 IT 或安全专业人士都可以理解。该船的建筑师解释说，他希望为所有乘客提供足够的救生艇，“但感觉甲板看起来太混乱了。”

这个决定在《泰坦尼克号》的后半部分具有悲剧性的意义，但时至今日，这个选择仍在各公司中被复制（尽管后果不那么可怕）。让领导层投资于漏洞预防是一个持续的挑战——许多领导者更愿意购买网络安全保险，并希望获得最好的结果。

然而，正如古代著名的沉船事故启发了当今有关救生艇的法律一样，有迹象表明无休止的数据泄露正在迫使对漏洞管理进行更大的投资。 （需要明确的是，我们谈论的是最广泛意义上的“漏洞管理”；而不仅仅是补丁管理。）

在过去几年中，NIST、SEC、ISO 和 PCI DSS 都发布了更新的指南，要求更加主动的漏洞管理。其中许多指南都特别强调了领导力的作用，例如美国证券交易委员会（SEC ）现在要求公司报告其经理和董事会如何处理漏洞。

这对于 IT 和安全团队来说是个好消息；在2023 年的一项调查中，50% 的受访者表示，他们组织的漏洞管理计划“在很大程度上”得到了领导层的支持。但显然，这仍然让 50% 的受访者感到冷落。

如果您想获得自己组织的支持，请了解有关您所面临风险的事实，并制定明确的补救计划。值得庆幸的是，有大量资源可以帮助您优先考虑您的需求。如果你还是没明白，欢迎你借用泰坦尼克号的比喻。

要了解有关漏洞管理如何变化的更多信息，请阅读完整的博客文章。

entry.title: [赞助商] 1Password：没有最高管理层的支持，安全只是重新布置躺椅
中国政府黑客破坏美国通信网络中的“好人后门”
entry.content:
Sarah Krouse、Dustin Volz、Aruna Viswanatha 和 Robert McMillan，《华尔街日报》报道：

据知情人士透露，黑客可能在数月或更长时间内掌握了用于配合美国对通信数据的合法请求的网络基础设施的访问权限，这构成了重大的国家安全风险。他们说，攻击者还可以访问其他部分更通用的互联网流量。知情人士称，Verizon Communications、AT&T 和 Lumen Technologies 等公司的网络因最近发现的入侵而遭到破坏。

这次广泛的妥协被认为是潜在的灾难性安全漏洞，是由一个名为 Salt Typhoon 的复杂的中国黑客组织实施的。知情人士称，它似乎是为了收集情报。 [...]

据信存在问题的监视系统用于配合提供与刑事和国家安全调查有关的国内信息的请求。根据联邦法律，电信和宽带公司必须允许当局根据法院命令拦截电子信息。目前还无法确定支持外国情报监视的系统是否也容易受到此次攻击的影响。

此事件今后应该成为反对任何网络或协议中“好人的后门”的典型例子。可以肯定地说，所有后门最终都会受到损害，这是不公平的，但通信越敏感和有价值，它们就越有可能受到损害。而这一点非常敏感且有价值。执法部门无法轻松拦截端到端加密通信是有缺点的，但后门的潜在缺点要严重得多。执法应该是一项艰苦的工作。

我们理应首先将这次袭击归咎于中国——美国政府应该开始将中国的此类袭击视为第二次冷战的一部分，并进行大规模报复——但次要的责任必须归咎于国会通过了《通讯》 1994 年颁布《执法协助法》(CALEA)，并于十年后向 FCC 提出扩大其解释的规定。法律要求 Verizon、AT&T 和其他网络遭到破坏的公司提供中国黑客利用的后门，而且现在仍然如此。

★

entry.title: 约翰·诺顿谈戴夫·维纳
entry.content:
约翰·诺顿（John Naughton）为《卫报》撰文：

一旦 RSS 提要的使用变得普遍，有人想到了可以将音频文件附加到它们上，戴夫以一种很好的极客风格实现了这个想法——附加一首 Grateful Dead 的歌曲。最初，这项新技术被称为音频博客，但最终一位英国记者提出了“播客”一词，并沿用至今。

因此，戴夫参与了一些很酷的东西的创作，但正是博客让他接触到了更广泛的公众。 “有些人生来就是为了演奏乡村音乐，”他曾写道。 “我生来就是为了写博客。刚开始写博客时，我以为每个人都会成为博主。我错了。大多数人没有冲动说出自己的想法。”戴夫则恰恰相反。他过去（现在仍然）善于表达且直率。他作为技术创新者的令人敬畏的记录意味着他不能被视为一个怪人。事实上，他在经济上有保障，这意味着他不必巴结任何人：他可以说出自己的想法。他做到了。因此，从 1994 年 10 月他推出 Scripting News 的那一刻起，他就成了网络上的佼佼者。

维纳的众多格言之一深深地引起了我的共鸣：人们会回到那些将他们送走的地方。

★
;

entry.title: Dave Winer 开创性博客 30 周年，脚本新闻
entry.content:
戴夫·维纳：

今天是这个博客成立 30 周年。你好！

当这个博客 25 岁时，我总结了一些想法。我坚持我当时写的内容，但我想补充一下。我开始写博客是因为我需要内容来测试我编写的脚本，该脚本使用Eudora在我的 Mac 上发送电子邮件，Eudora 是一个早期的可编写脚本的应用程序，我有一个很好的脚本系统可以使用它。我四处寻找要发送的内容（30 年前的今天），然后向那些我在各种技术会议上收集了名片的人发出了一封电子邮件。这太令人兴奋了，所以我又做了一次，又做了三遍，然后我才意识到，嘿，我可以用这个东西来表达我自己的想法。就这样开始了我至今仍在做的事情。看看我最近几天写的关于 WordPress 的两篇文章。也许有希望在那里找到埋藏的博客圈。也许可以为他们提供一些可爱的新写作工具，这样他们就可以像我们多年前那样对网络写作感到兴奋。我实际上对此持乐观态度。也许我们可以在喧嚣中站起来。大约 20 年前，当我们推出播客时，我们有一个口号——“用户和开发者一起聚会”。成功了！这仍然是我想要构建东西的方式，这是我知道如何去做的唯一方式。博客最初是一种编程冒险，最终成为一种文学形式。怎么样？如果你们都愿意的话，我愿意做更多这样的事情。但请期待做出贡献，不要期望这一切都是免费的，因为我们知道没有什么是真正免费的。

Winer 因其技术成就而闻名——大纲作为一种应用程序类型、一般的 RSS，以及特定播客背景下的 RSS——但是什么让我在 Scripting News 的整个 30 年里一直阅读 Scripting News奔跑是他的写作。他拥有如此独特的写作声音，这是在网络以外的任何媒体中无法想象的。但我认为这是因为他不仅帮助定义了网络写作的含义，甚至定义了网络写作的含义。

谢谢你所做的一切，戴夫。

★
;

entry.content:
艾玛·罗斯 (Emma Roth) 总结了 WordPress 商业部门和主要 WordPress 托管提供商 WP Engine 之间复杂且快速发展的法律纠纷：

在过去的几周里，WordPress 联合创始人 Matt Mullenweg 明确表示了一件事：他负责 WordPress 的未来。

Mullenweg 领导着 WordPress.com 及其母公司 Automattic。他拥有 WordPress.org 项目，甚至领导着控制 WordPress 商标的非营利基金会。对于外部观察者来说，这些可能看起来是独立的组织，都是围绕 WordPress 开源项目单独设计的。但当 Mullenweg 与第三方 WordPress 托管服务 WP Engine 展开斗争时，他混淆了三个基本实体之间的界限，这三个实体领导着一个庞大的生态系统，为几乎一半的网络提供动力。

对于 Mullenweg 来说，这一切都很好——只要它能够支持 WordPress 的长期健康发展。

entry.title: 在 iPhone 上设置 VPN（无需应用程序）

昨天关于俄罗斯要求 Apple 从俄罗斯应用商店中删除 VPN 应用程序的项目的重要后续内容：您可以在没有应用程序的 iOS 上使用 VPN。它只需要在设置和支持它的 VPN 提供商中进行一些调整。据推测，俄罗斯的 iPhone 用户仍然可以使用这项技术。以下是来自此类 VPN 提供商 ForestVPN 的说明：

    • 打开 iPhone 上的“设置”应用。
    • 点击常规并滚动至 VPN 和设备管理。
  2. 添加VPN配置：
    • 选择添加 VPN 配置。
    • 选择您所需的协议，例如 L2TP 或 IKEv2。
  3. 输入 VPN 详细信息：
    • 填写必要的字段，如描述、服务器、远程 ID 和本地 ID。这些详细信息可以在 ForestVPN 网站上找到。
  4. 保存并连接：
    • 点击完成以保存您的配置。
    • 通过切换新创建的配置文件旁边的开关来启用 VPN。

VPN 应用程序消除了此过程的复杂性，但值得注意的是 VPN 访问不需要应用程序。

entry.title: 应 YouTube 的要求，Juno 已从 App Store 中删除
entry.content:
克里斯蒂安·塞利格：

对于那些不知道的人来说，几个月前，在联系我后， YouTube 联系了 App Store，表示 Juno 不遵守 YouTube 指南，并以他们不同意的方式修改网站，并暗示了他们的商标和图像。

我个人并不同意这一点，因为 Juno 只是一个 Web 视图，其作用只不过是一个浏览器扩展，它修改 CSS 以使网站和视频播放器看起来更像“visionOS”。除网站上已有的徽标外，不得放置任何徽标，并且其品牌指南中允许使用“for YouTube”后缀。出于好奇，朱诺也不会以任何方式屏蔽广告。

我向 YouTube 说了这么多，他们不会真正澄清或做出任何让步，由于双方无法得出结论，几分钟前我收到了苹果发来的一封电子邮件，称 Juno 已从应用程序中删除店铺。

至少可以说，这很糟糕。 Juno 是一款出色的 VisionOS 应用程序 - 该平台最好的第三方应用程序之一。它将 YouTube 视频观看从 Safari 中完全平庸的体验变成了作为本机应用程序的完全令人惊叹的体验。 Juno 并不是阻止人们使用 YouTube 自己的本机应用程序，因为众所周知，根本就没有这样的应用程序。 YouTube 发言人二月份在 The Verge 上告诉 Nilay Patel ，“Vision Pro 应用程序已在我们的路线图上”，但正如我当时所写，“考虑到 Google iOS 应用程序的设计质量和对平台设计习惯的遵守（差） ，我不确定他们是否有能力制作朱诺质量的应用程序。”

我仍然坚持这一点。我预计 YouTube 不会很快推出原生 VisionOS 应用程序，即使他们这样做，我也怀疑它是否会像 Juno 一样好。在那篇 2 月份的帖子中，我明显错误地认为 YouTube 不会关心 Juno 的存在，因为 Juno 没有屏蔽广告。它所做的只是让 Vision Pro 上的 YouTube 体验变得更好。

这使得 Selig——当今苹果平台上最有天赋的独立开发者之一——受到大平台的青睐，Selig 为这些平台创建了精心设计的客户端。 （当然，第一个是他心爱的 Reddit 客户端 Apollo 。）如果他采取 3 for 3，Phil Schiller 应该给予他“三连胜”终生免收 App Store 佣金的机会。

entry.title: “Meta 和 Apple：同样的游戏，不同的规则”
entry.content:
杰森·斯内尔，《六种颜色》：

这些公司玩着同样的游戏，但方式不同。谁领先？我认为这是不可能的，因为如果苹果有像 Orion 这样的产品，我们永远不会看到它。我们可以争论苹果公司永远、永远不对未发布的产品发表评论的强制措施是否有益，但这是史蒂夫·乔布斯创造的苹果个性，不太可能很快被取消。

猎户座原型机的脆弱程度可见一斑。 Meta 声称其成本为 10,000 美元，但他们没有透露这是商品成本还是零售价。但让我们假设他们今天将其推向市场时零售价仅为 10,000 美元。那很贵。但这并不荒谬。您可以花这么多钱购买高端工作站级台式机。一台全规格的 16 英寸 MacBook Pro 售价为 7,200 美元。

但据 The Verge 报道，这些 Orion 原型机的电池续航时间只有 2 小时。而且它们太厚太粗了。穿上它们，你看起来很奇怪，甚至丑陋。因此，Meta 不仅需要将价格降低至少 3 倍（这将使 Vision Pro 的价格约为 3,500 美元，大多数评论家认为该价格太贵），他们还需要将眼镜做得更小 —更加苗条——同时显着延长电池寿命。这两个因素是直接矛盾的。延长电池寿命的唯一简单方法是在设备中放置更大的电池，这会使设备本身更厚更重。 （参见今年的 iPhone 16 Pro。）

从各方面来看，Orion 都是一个非常引人注目的演示。但它也很明显是一个只适合演示的原型设备。即使零售价为 10,000 美元，它在今天也不会引人注目。然而不知何故，Meta 希望我们相信他们对一款价格诱人的消费品有“视线”。

令人兴奋的是他们公开展示了 Orion，但我认为这对 Meta 的未来没有任何帮助。苹果没有在 2004 年展示 iPhone 原型机是有原因的。

 defaults write com.apple.dock slow-motion-allowed -bool YES

然后重新启动 Dock：

 killall Dock

或者，在单个命令中：

 defaults write com.apple.dock slow-motion-allowed -bool YES; killall Dock

entry.title: 首席技术官 Mira Murati 突然离开 OpenAI，该公司现已成为一家营利性公司
entry.content:
Deepa Seetharaman、Berber Jin 和 Tom Dotan，《华尔街日报》报道（新闻+ ）：

OpenAI 计划从一家非营利组织转变为一家营利性公司，同时该公司正在进行重大人事变动，其中包括周三其首席技术官 Mira Murati 突然辞职。 OpenAI 成立于 2015 年，成立时发布的一份声明称，成为营利性组织将是一个巨大的转变，其目的是开发人工智能技术，“造福整个人类，不受产生财务回报的需要的限制”。

我想我没有给予足够的关注，但我错误地认为关于将 OpenAI 转变为营利性公司的整个辩论在一年前就已经决定了，当时的董事会解雇了 Sam Altman，因为他利润驱动，然后董事会自行解散，奥特曼被带回来。

2022 年底，事情开始发生变化，它发布了 ChatGPT，一炮而红，并引发了全球对生成式人工智能重塑商业和社会潜力的兴趣。在首席执行官 Sam Altman 的指导下，OpenAI 开始为消费者和企业客户发布新产品，并聘请了大量销售、战略和财务人员。员工，包括一些从早期就加入该公司的员工，开始抱怨该公司将产品运输置于其构建安全人工智能系统的最初使命之上。

一些人离开了其他公司或创办了自己的公司，包括竞争对手人工智能初创公司 Anthropic 。今年的外流尤其明显。在Murati之前，OpenAI联合创始人、前首席科学家Ilya Sutskever 、联合创始人、前顶级研究员John Schulman、前顶级研究员Jan Leike均自5月份起辞职。联合创始人兼前总裁格雷格·布罗克曼 (Greg Brockman) 最近休假至年底。

根据Altman 在 X 上发布的帖子，除了 Murati 之外，首席研究官 Bob McGrew 和培训后主管 Barret Zoph也将离开 OpenAI。

OpenAI 与微软和苹果都建立了高调的合作伙伴关系，这两家公司数十年来都拥有极其稳定的执行领导力。但 OpenAI 本身似乎一直处于高管混乱和动荡的状态。这对我来说有点令人头疼。

entry.content:
我将首先链接到 The Verge 的“ Meta Connect 2024 上宣布的一切”综述，因为 Meta 尚未在 YouTube 上发布今天的主题演讲；我发现的最好的就是这段直播录音，从 43 分 20 秒左右开始。我现场观看了大部分主题演讲，发现它很吸引人。只有 45 分钟长——部分原因是信息密集，部分原因是马克·扎克伯格亲自主持了整个活动。他最近看起来很自在、自信、自然。没有什么比一堆副总裁更能拖慢台上主题演讲的节奏了。在这次主题演讲中，Meta 显然没有出现政治内讧。基调是扎克的，因此，它有力而轻快。

就实际发货的实际产品而言，Meta 宣布了售价300 美元的 Quest 3S 。这比 Vision Pro 的价格低了整整一个数量级。 Vision Pro 的功能可能比 Quest 3S 强 10 倍以上，但我不确定它是否只适合玩游戏和看电影，这可能是人们目前唯一想用耳机做的事情。他们还推出了7,500 副限量版，售价 430 美元，实际上颇受欢迎的 Ray-Ban Wayfarer“智能”眼镜由 iMac 风格的半透明塑料制成。自从有人制造“看看内部”消费设备以来已经有一段时间了。这很有趣，也有点古怪。

最重要的展示是 Orion，一款透明 AR 眼镜的工作原型。 Meta 本身将它们描述为“开发套件”，但它们不仅无法购买，而且不可用，就这样。它们是 Meta 自己的开发人员的内部原型，而不是外部开发人员。对于演示来说，它们确实看起来很有趣，而且我从门洛帕克现场的抖动记者那里听说，使用它们确实很引人注目。毫无疑问，实际的眼镜是 AR 的外形因素。

今天，The Verge 的亚历克斯·希思 (Alex Heath) 在他关于猎户座的文章中这样开头：

它们看起来几乎就像一副普通的眼镜。

这将“几乎”的含义延伸到了极限。我想说它们看起来有点像一副普通的眼镜。镜框（超级粗）和镜片（厚，棱柱形，有时发光）都很引人注目。它们看起来像矫形眼镜，旨在帮助那些视力低到法定盲人的人。确实，Meta 的雷朋 Wayfarers 与普通 Wayfarers 几乎没有什么区别。猎户座根本不是那样的。如果您带着这些设备出现在公共场合（您不能这样做，因为它们是内部原型），每个人都会注意到您戴着某种科技眼镜，或者可能会认为您走出电影院时没有归还 3D风镜。但是：如果你愿意的话，你可以在公共场合佩戴它们，而且与在公共场合佩戴 VR 耳机不同，你看起来只是一个书呆子， 而不是一个混蛋。他们很接近某事。但距离真正重要的东西有多近，尤其是在价格方面，是值得商榷的。来自希斯的报告：

正如 Meta 的高管复述的那样，搁置 Orion 的决定主要是因为该设备的制造成本天文数字，每台大约为 10,000 美元。大部分成本是由于可靠地制造碳化硅透镜非常困难且昂贵。当开始设计 Orion 时，Meta 预计这种材料将在整个行业中得到更广泛的应用，从而变得更便宜，但这一情况并没有发生。

“你无法想象产量有多么可怕，”Meta 首席技术官 Andrew Bosworth 谈到镜头时说道。相反，该公司转而生产约 1,000 副 Orion 眼镜，用于内部开发和外部演示。

Snap 最近推出了他们的新款 Spectacles ，他们以每年 1,200 美元的价格出租而不是出售。 Snap 的眼镜非常粗壮，与 Orion 相比显得不那么显眼。但将 AR 眼镜推向市场的竞赛显然已经开始。

另请参阅： 希思 (Heath) 对扎克伯格 (Zuckerberg) 的《解码器》采访。

第二天附录：今天早上我醒来时，脑海中浮现出以下竞争性的来回：

  1. Facebook 推出了 VR 耳机和软件平台，非常强调“虚拟宇宙”，因此他们将公司重新命名为 Meta。
  2. 相比之下，苹果公司宣布并在 7 个月后发布了 Vision Pro，它传达了两个信息：（a）“元宇宙”这个东西太愚蠢了，他们甚至不会使用这个术语； (b) 极其卓越的分辨率和体验质量。然而，消费者的反应却并不令人印象深刻。
  3. Meta 放弃了“metaverse”这个词，并预览了 Orion，有效地宣称他们认为 VR 耳机是错误的东西，以创建定义个人计算领域下一个突破性变革的产品。我们的目标是 AR 眼镜，而不是 VR 耳机。

这需要大量的来回讨论，这使得新设备前沿的早期阶段令人兴奋且高度不确定。大胆的想法被尝试过，但大多数都以死胡同而告终。与过去 20 年我们在笔记本电脑方面的发展情况或近年来我们在手机方面似乎达到的顶峰进行比较和对比。

entry.summary: 对于一款高级壁纸应用来说，每年 50 美元的价格是完全合理的。但面板并不是一款高级应用程序。
entry.content:
MKBHD 的一次失误。对该应用程序的批评在两个单独的层面上，但它们被混为一谈。级别1：应用不好。级别2：付费壁纸应用？ - 大声笑，壁纸在reddit上是免费的。第二种形式的批评 - 甚至不应该存在付费墙纸应用程序 - 令人烦恼和沮丧，并谈到有多少人不认为原始艺术值得付出。但这也说明了Brownlee的观众的广度，我认为这比以设计为以设计为中心更为专注。斯科特·史密斯（Scott Smith），关于马斯托登（Mastodon），观察到：

将@iconfactory的独立iOS社区与主流技术社区对@MKBHD的面板的反应进行比较，这真的很有趣。我知道他们无论如何都不相同，但它阐明了主流技术圈中有多少人在为艺术品支付付款方面仍然感到震惊。

就是这样，就是这样。在某种程度上，可以忽略廉价的廉价味道视角。如果一个人的论点是所有壁纸应该是免费的，那不是批评付费壁纸应用程序/服务的有效起点。

问题是，面板不是一个好应用：

  • 在iPhone上的第一次运行期间，它撞到了我。

  • UI大且球茎大，虽然它在iOS和Android上看起来几乎相同（这可能是为什么它如此粗糙的原因），但它在两个平台上看起来都是本地的。它看起来和感觉更像是游戏的界面，而不是应用程序。如果有的话，它看起来和感觉比iOS-y更具Android-y，即使只是因为“在任何地方都看上去都不看起来本地人”更像是一件Android的事情。如果布朗利（Brownlee）对这个应用程序的外观和感觉都陷入困境，那么它就可以（更多） （更多）说明他愿意花费大量时间日常驾驶的Android手机。

  • 完全主观，但我认为壁纸本身并不好。我的意思是没有一个。他们觉得自己是用户生成的内容，而不是像布朗利这样的值得信赖的口味制造商策划的专业内容。

  • 该应用程序具有CRUMMY隐私报告卡，包括使用您的一般位置进行跟踪，并且在iOS上提出了“要求不跟踪”对话框。在Android上更糟。不优质。 （面板不要求GPS位置访问，但它使用您的IP地址进行跟踪，Apple将其归类为“位置”。苹果应该阐明App Store隐私报告卡中的区别 - 要求GPS在所有这些都是基于IP的地理位置 - 但对于应用程序来说，这是一个不好的外观。）

  • “ SD”（1080p）壁纸可以免费从某些创作者那里下载，但需要观看一两分钟的视频广告。不优质。

  • 订阅的价格为每年50美元或每月12美元（每年144美元！），至少可以说是高价。 （ Wallaroo是一个更好的应用程序，其主观上的壁纸要好得多，每年20美元或每月$ 2）。

高级壁纸应用程序可以证明每年50美元的价格是合理的，这是完全合理的。但是面板不是高级应用程序。高级应用程序不会要求在应用程序中跟踪您。高级应用程序不会让您观看广告以获取免费内容。高级应用程序外观和感觉到其平台。高级应用程序没有粗略的隐私报告卡。就目前而言，面板是不协调和不一致的。

entry.summary: 除了每年新型号的背面，相机镜头不断增长，还是“ iPhone on iPhone shot”广告系列，对相机对iPhone的奇特重要性的证明还需要什么？专用硬件按钮？
entry.content:
史蒂夫·乔布斯（Steve Jobs）2007年推出原始iPhone的众多令人难忘的时刻之一是这款幻灯片显示了市场上当时领先的智能手机中的四台。工作解释：

现在，为什么我们需要革命性的用户界面？这是四个智能手机，对吗？摩托罗拉Q，黑莓，棕榈树，诺基亚E62 - 通常的嫌疑人。而且，他们的用户界面有什么问题？好吧，他们的问题确实在40的底部。这是那里的东西。他们都有这些键盘，无论您是否需要它们在那里。而且它们都具有这些控制按钮，这些按钮固定在塑料中，并且对于每个应用程序都是相同的。好吧，每个应用程序都需要一个略有不同的用户界面，一组略有优化的按钮，只是为此。

如果您从现在开始六个月后，您会想到一个好主意会怎样？您无法四处奔跑并在这些事情中添加一个按钮。他们已经发货了。那么你做什么呢？它不起作用，因为按钮和控件无法更改。他们无法为每个应用程序更改，如果您想到要添加到此产品中的另一个好主意，他们将无法改变道路。

那么，你如何解决这个问题呢？唔。事实证明，我们已经解决了它。我们在20年前在计算机中解决了它。我们用位图屏幕解决了它，该屏幕可以显示我们想要的任何内容。将任何用户界面放置。和指向设备。我们用鼠标解决了它。我们解决了这个问题。那么，我们将如何将其带到移动设备？我们要做的就是摆脱所有这些按钮，然后制作一个巨大的屏幕。一个巨大的屏幕。

当时，似乎最激进的是避​​开了硬件Qwerty键盘，而是在软件中实现触摸屏键盘。当时的微软首席执行官史蒂夫·鲍尔默（Steve Ballmer）在臭名昭著的剪辑中，在被要求看到iPhone的反应后，他嘲笑了他：“ 500美元？完全补贴，有计划吗？我说，这是世界上最昂贵的手机，它不吸引商业客户，因为它没有键盘，这使其不是一台很好的电子邮件机。”

当然，苹果并没有摆脱所有按钮。但是他们保留的按钮全部用于系统，设备，而不是任何特定的应用：电源，音量，静音开关（奇怪的是，几乎没有竞争对手复制），前面面上的唯一按钮： 。 1就是这样。

当苹果的竞争对手停止嘲笑iPhone并开始复制iPhone时，他们摆脱了硬件键盘 - 其主要指示符与常规手机区分了“智能手机” - 但他们无法带来自己来消除不是一个专门的，而是两个专用的手机对于他们的不想像力的硬件按钮是使任何手机成为手机的固有的：绿色的“呼叫”和红色“挂断”按钮。 Android手机具有那些红色/绿色按钮。黑莓风暴也有它们。除iPhone以外的每部手机都有它们。直到他们赶上并意识到这些按钮也被避开。

这种想法可能植根于设备的名称。当然，所有手机 - 愚蠢的电话，黑莓风格的硬件键盘手机，iPhone风格的触摸屏电话 - 都应该有电话按钮。我怀疑他们非常深刻地思考了苹果的大胆如何足以避开硬件键盘，以进行全触摸屏设计，但是他们认为苹果只是通过避开绿色/红色硬件呼叫按钮来使极简主义变得极端。无论他们做多少其他事情，都是电话 - 它的名字就在那里！

但是iPhone从来没有真正成为电话。在iPhone上，手机始终只是另一个应用程序。一个特殊的应用程序，毫无疑问。默认位置在主屏幕底部的码头中。特殊的背景特权在原本高度约束的操作系统中，当您返回主屏幕时，大多数应用程序都会有效地退出。即将到来的电话立即接管了整个屏幕。 Jobs在该简介中花费了大量时间展示电话应用程序 - 包括Visual Voicemail，这是一项真正的突破性功能，需要AT＆T/Cingular的后端合作。 2

但是，当时，iPhone的电话部分仍然是一个应用程序。如果您将iPhone与iPod Touch进行了比较，那么iPhone硬件上没有什么比iPod Touch更重要的是手机，这不仅不是手机，而且甚至没有提供蜂窝网络。肯定没有按钮。无粘性天线。设备上没有载波徽标。看看现代的iPhone，实际上只有一个功能从显着的硬件突出中可以清楚地看到其目的：相机镜头。五年前，在我对iPhone 11的评论的Lede中，我写道：“几周前，我的播客中，猜测今年的新iPhone的Tentpole功能，我说'icamera'将是更加贴切的名称而不是“ iPhone”。”

与每年新型号的后面不断增长的相机镜头或“ iPhone上的镜头”广告系列相比）苹果历史上的运动？专用硬件按钮？

相机控制

便利的看法是，苹果已经用完了硬件的想法，现在每年只为iPhone添加一个新按钮 - 去年的动作按钮，今年的摄像机控制，也许他们明年终于添加了那些绿色/红色的电话按钮。但这在低估了iPhone第18届年度硬件迭代中Apple的根本性，以添加专用于单个应用程序的硬件按钮。

我的意思是，从一般意义上讲，不仅仅是应用程序意义。默认情况下，当然，按下摄像头控制启动iOS相机应用程序3 ，但是在设置任何新的iPhone 16时，Apple自己的入职屏幕将其目的描述为启动“摄像机应用程序”，并使用小写c 。任何采用新API和指南的第三方应用程序都可以用作摄像机应用程序，该应用程序将通过相机控制启动（并启动，一旦启动，控制）。 （不过，我默认写有关使用系统摄像机应用程序的文章。）

苹果似乎从未将相机控制称为“按钮”，但这是一个按钮。您可以看到它的凹陷，即使设备电源关闭，它也会单击（与Yore iPhone上的Haptic Touch ID Home按钮不同，Yore和长时间的iPhone SE）。但这不仅是一个按钮。您可以将其视为两个物理控件：一个微型触觉滑块（例如只有一个轴的触控板）和一个实际单击的按钮。

当相机应用程序尚未处于拍摄模式时（无论您的iPhone在锁定屏幕上还是其他应用程序都处于活动状态），即使您在拍摄以外在相机应用程序中进行其他操作，例如查看现有照片）：

  • 完全单击相机控制按钮将启动相机应用程序（如有必要），并将您处于射击模式。
  • 轻时，什么也没有触发，也没有提供任何触觉反馈。当您在相机应用中准备拍摄时，光线只能做点什么。

当相机应用活动处于活动状态并准备拍摄时：

  • 完全单击相机控件按钮，请拍摄照片或启动视频，具体取决于您当前的模式。 （如果您处于仍处于光片模式，请单击和挂载的摄像头控件将启动视频，就像按下屏幕上的快门按钮一样。）
  • 摄像机控件上的轻度按下覆盖层，可通过将手指从左到右滑动，即触控板式，可以调整当前设置模式。
  • 摄像机控件上的双重按下会更改覆盖层以选择要调整的设置。选项是：曝光，深度（ƒ停留），变焦，摄像头，样式，音调。

只要写出所有内容，就会听起来很复杂，而且有点复杂。 （这是Apple自己的使用相机控制的插图指南。）相机很复杂。但是，如果您只是将其捣碎，那就拍照。相机控制就像相机应用本身的缩影。只想指向并射击？简单的。是否想摆弄ƒ停留和样式？有一个周到的UI可以做到这一点。在iPhone的早期， Apple的Camera App确实很简单。拍摄接口只有几个按钮：快门，照片/视频切换，闪光灯的控件以及用于切换到前置摄像头的切换。原始的iPhone和iPhone 3G甚至不支持视频，直到iPhone 4之前，前置摄像头才到达。这些旧的iPhone具有简单的相机硬件，并且该应用程序反映了这种简单性。

苹果的现代相机硬件变得非常复杂，相机应用也具有。但是，如果您只想拍摄您在取景器中看到的东西，那就一如既往地简单。捏到缩放，点击以聚焦，按下快门按钮进行射击。但是，还有许多其他的控件和选项，很容易获得，并为那些想要它们的人提供了巧妙的介绍，而那些不愿意的人很容易被那些没有的人忽略。苹果的相机应用程序是世界上最好的软件之一，也是最精心设计的软件之一。可以说，这也是世界上最受欢迎的界面。您很难找到一部单个高级Android手机，其内置相机应用看起来不像Apple的应用，通常直到文本标签的黄色重音颜色。

使用几个iPhone 16评论单元一周多了之后，我对相机控制的摘要是要习惯 - 我觉得我仍然习惯了 - 但已经感觉像是我不想要的东西不做。这是一个好主意，也是一个大胆的主意。正如我上面强调的那样，只有在第18个硬件修订中，Apple添加了一个专用于单个应用程序的硬件控件。我不希望苹果再做一次。我确实希望苹果的竞争对手可以无耻地复制相机控制。

显而易见的是，摄影爱好者在苹果中的摄影爱好者对摄影爱好者的工作和感觉非常熟悉。在政治上，它一定是由同一群体倡导的。现在，现在有一个专门用于所有新iPhone的摄影的硬件控制确实令人震惊，这是一个机械复杂的控制。

摄影，除了相机控制

像往常一周）相机似乎和往常一样好。

今年的新摄影功能与镜头或传感器无关。这是下一代摄影风格，实际上是“对我们其他人的原始”。这一直是我个人摄影奇特里/热情的边缘。我非常关心摄影，可以在数十年中购买了许多千美元的摄像头（和镜头），但是拍摄Raw从来没有对我坚持。我了解它是什么，以及为什么它在技术上优于射击JPEG/HEIC，但这太多了。 RAW使您可以通过POST中的手动开发获得更好的结果，但是您必须在Post中开发，因为原始图像（对不起）看起来很平坦且不饱和。有一段时间，我尝试拍摄RAW + JPEG，其中您拍摄的每个图像都被存储为直接发达的原始文件，又存储了一个模仿pipeline jpeg文件，但事实证明我是从来没有回过头来开发那些原始图像。相对于JPEG/HEIC（从此以后，我只是为了简洁起来称为“射击JPEG”，即使iPhone自七年前11年前iOS违约了效率提高的HEIC格式），Raw Image占10次，RAW Image占10 ×（或更多）存储空间。

太麻烦了。对于我来说，图像质量的提高我可以消除开发RAW，这是不值得付出的努力。对于许多认真的摄影师而言。每个人都有这样的台词。有些人根本不做任何编辑。他们从不裁剪，从不改变邮政中的曝光，永远不要应用过滤器 - 它们只是指向并射击而完成。对我来说，那条线正在开枪。

苹果三年前13年前首次使用iPhone引入摄影风格，具有四种自我描述的主要风格：丰富的对比度（我的选择），充满活力，温暖和酷。每种主要样式都提供自定义。找到您喜欢的样式，将其设置为默认设置，然后走上快乐的方式。但是，无论您选择的哪种样式都是iPhone硬件成像管道“开发”照片的方式。多年来，苹果的“过滤器”一直没有破坏性，但是第一代摄影风格被烘烤到它写入存储的HEIC文件中。

使用iPhone 16阵容，此功能现在更加强大，同时保持方便且易于使用。 5苹果消除了以前称为“过滤器”的东西，并重新创建了更好的样式（例如充满活力和戏剧性的）。现在有15种基础样式可供选择，其中大多数是自我描述的（中性，黄金，玫瑰金），一些诗意的命名（舒适，安静，空灵）。默认样式被命名为标准，它以看起来像iPhone-y的方式处理图像。到目前为止，我迷恋的两个人是自然而鲜明的B＆W。对于我们的许多眼睛来说，标准的iPhone图像处理长期以来一直略有处理。降低噪音过多，平滑过多。有点太强烈。自然在我眼中确实看起来更自然。 Stark B＆W想到了经典的高对比度黑白电影，例如Kodak Tri-X 400 。

现在，摄影风格的一个关键方面是它们无损。您可以在帖子中改变主意。将默认设置设置为Stark B＆W，然后在照片中进行编辑，您可以使用所需的其他样式改变主意，然后返回全彩色图像。幕后有很多复杂的图像处理 - 包括iPhone 16硬件和iOS 18软件 - 使这似乎没什么大不了的。但是，由于新的摄影风格在很大程度上是基于硬件成像管道的（或完全？），因此即使在升级到iOS 18之后，iPhone 13-15仍将继续使用第一代摄影风格。

我一直对我懒得开枪的事实感到有些内gui。我怀疑，iPhone 16阵容中的这种下一代摄影风格可能会缓解这种罪恶感的剩余遗迹。

And because I don't, I can't remember the last time I needed to transfer data from my iPhone via the USB-C port, so, while the Pro models offer a noticeable advantage in USB performance, I might never use it personally在明年。

Another difference is that the 16 Pro models have slightly bigger displays than the regular 16 models. The 16 Pro and 16 Pro Max are 6.3 and 6.9 inches; the regular 16 and 16 Plus are 6.1 and 6.7. Whether that's actually an advantage for the Pro models depends on whether you care that they're also slightly taller and heavier devices in hand.

电池寿命

I omitted from the above comparison the one spec people care most about: battery life. Here is the sleeper spec where the Pro models earn their keep. Once again grouping like-vs.-like size classes, and including the 15 Pro models for year-over-year comparison:

模型视频Video (streamed)
15 Pro 23小时20小时
16 22小时18小时
16 Pro 27小时22小时
15 Pro Max 29小时25小时
16加号27小时24小时
16 专业最大33小时29小时

Those battery life numbers come from Apple, not my own testing (and Apple cites them as “up to” numbers). But those numbers suggest 20 percent longer battery life on the 16 Pro models compared to their size-class non-pro counterparts. Anecdotally, that feels true to me. I use a Shortcuts automation to turn on Low Power mode whenever my iPhone battery level drops below 35 percent. With my iPhone 15 Pro, that generally happens every night at some point. Over the last week using the iPhone 16 Pro as my primary iPhone, it hasn't dropped that low most nights. To say the least, that's not a rigorous test in any way, shape, or form. But Apple has no history of exaggerating battery life claims, especially relative comparisons between devices. I think it's the real deal, and the 16 Pro and 16 Pro Max probably get 20 percent longer battery life than their corresponding 16 and 16 Plus counterparts, and between 10–15 percent over last year's Pro models, in practical day-to-day使用。

That alone might be worth a big chunk of the $200 price difference to some people.

苹果情报

I spent the weekdays last week running iOS 18.0; on Friday afternoon, I upgraded my 16 Pro review unit to the developer beta of iOS 18.1 (beta 3 at the time, since upgraded to beta 4). I'm sure many, if not most reviewers, will review only what comes in the box, and what's coming in the box this week will be iOS 18.0 without any Apple Intelligence features.

That stance is fair enough, but I don't see it as a big deal to include my 18.1 experience in this review. iOS 18.1 feels pretty close to shipping. Apple has promised “October”, and my gut feeling, using it for the last five days on this review unit, is that it's pretty solid. I suspect it might ship closer to early October than late October. But even if it doesn't appear until Halloween, I don't think it's absurd or offensive that Apple is already using Apple Intelligence to market the iPhone 16 lineup. It's a little awkward right now, but it's not a sham. It's vaporware until it actually ships, but it's vaporware that anyone with a developer account can install right now.

Also, none of the Apple Intelligence features currently in iOS 18.1 are game-changing. The Clean Up feature in Photos is pretty good, and when it doesn't produce good results, you can simply revert to the original. The AI-generated summaries of messages, notifications, and emails in Mail are at times apt, but at others not so much . I haven't tried the Rewrite tool because I'm, let's face it, pretty confident in my own writing ability. But, after my own final editing pass, I ran this entire review through the Proofread feature, and it correctly flagged seven mistakes I missed, and an eighth that I had marked, but had forgotten to fix. Most of its suggestions that I have chosen to ignore were, by the book, legitimate. (Eg, it suggested replacing the jargon-y lede with the standard spelling lead . It also flagged my stubborn capitalization of “MacOS”.) It took 1 minute, 45 seconds to complete the proofreading pass of the 7,200+ words in Apple Notes on the iPhone 16 Pro. (Subsequent to the original publication of this review, I tried the Rewrite function on the text of it, for shits and giggles, and the only way I can describe the results is that it gave up.)

New Siri definitely offers a cooler-looking visual interface. And the new Siri voices sound more natural. But it also feels like Siri is speaking too slowly, as though Siri hails from the Midwest or something. (Changing Siri's speaking rate to 110 percent in Settings → Accessibility → Siri sounds much more natural to my ears, and feels like it matches old Siri's speaking rate.) Type to Siri is definitely cool, but I don't see why we couldn't have had that feature since 2010. I have actually used the new “Product Knowledge” feature, where Siri draws upon knowledge from Apple's own support documentation, while writing this review.这很棒。 But maybe Apple's support website should have had better search years ago?

These are all good features. But let's say you never heard of LLMs or ChatGPT. And instead, at WWDC this year, without any overarching “Apple Intelligence” marketing umbrella, Apple had simply announced features like a new cool-looking Siri interface, typing rather than talking to Siri, being able to remove unwanted background objects from photos, a “proofreading” feature for the standard text system that extends and improves the years-old but (IMO) kinda lame grammar-checking feature on MacOS, and brings it to iOS too? Those would seem like totally normal features Apple might add this year. But not tentpole features. These Apple Intelligence features strike me as nothing more than the sort of nice little improvements Apple makes across its OSes every year.

Apple reiterated throughout last week's “It's Glowtime” keynote, and now in its advertising for the iPhone 16 lineup , that these are the first iPhones “built for Apple Intelligence from the ground up”.我不是买那个。 These are simply the second generation of iPhone models with enough RAM to run on-device LLMs. LLMs are breakthrough technology. But they're breakthroughs at the implementation level. The technology is fascinating and important, but so are things like the Swift programming language. I spent the first half of my time testing the iPhone 16 Pro running iOS 18.0 and the second half running 18.1 with Apple Intelligence. A few things got a little nicer.就是这样。

I might be underselling how impossible the Clean Up feature would be without generative AI. I am very likely underselling how valuable the new writing tools might prove to people trying to write in a second language, or who simply aren't capable of expressing themselves well in their first language. But like I said, they're all good features. I just don't see them as combining to form the collective tentpole that Apple is marketing “Apple Intelligence” as. I get it that from Apple's perspective, engineering-wise, it's like adding an entire platform to the existing OS. It's a massive engineering effort and the on-device execution constraints are onerous. But from a user's perspective, they're just ... features. When's the last year Apple has not added cool new features along the scope of these?

Apple's just riding — and now, through the impressive might of its own advertising and marketing, contributing to — the AI hype wave, and I find that a little eye-roll inducing. It would have been cooler, in an understated breathe-on-your-fingernails-and-polish-them-on-your-shirt kind of way, if Apple had simply added these same new features across their OSes without the marketing emphasis being on the “Apple Intelligence” umbrella. If not for the AI hype wave the industry is currently caught in, this emphasis on which features are part of “Apple Intelligence” would seem as strange as Apple emphasizing, in advertisements, which apps are now built using SwiftUI.

If the iPhone 16 lineup was “built from the ground up” with a purpose in mind, it's to serve as the best prosumer cameras ever made. Not to create cartoon images of a dog blowing out candles on a birthday cake . The new lineup of iPhones 16 are amazing devices. The non-pro iPhone 16 and 16 Plus arguably offer the best value-per-dollar of any iPhones Apple has ever made. This emphasis on Apple Intelligence distracts from that.

The problem isn't that Apple is marketing Apple Intelligence a few weeks before it's actually going to ship. It's that few of these features are among the coolest or most interesting things about the new iPhone 16 lineup, and none are unique advantages that only Apple has the ability or inclination to offer. 7 Every phone on the market will soon be able to generate impersonal saccharine passages of text and uncanny-valley images via LLMs. Only Apple has the talent and passion to create something as innovative and genuinely useful as Camera Control.

  1. While I'm reminiscing, allow me to reiterate my belief that the icon on the iPhone Home button is the single greatest icon ever designed. In my 2017 review of the iPhone X , I wrote:

    The fundamental premise of iOS Classic is that a running app gets the entire display, and the Home button is how you interact with the system to get out of the current app and into another. Before Touch ID, the Home button was even labeled with a generic empty “app” icon, an iconographic touch of brilliance. [...]

    I find it hard to consider a world where that button was marked by an icon that looked like a house (the overwhelmingly common choice for a “home” icon) or printed with the word “ HOME ” (the way iPods had a “ MENU ”按钮）。 Early iPhone prototypes did, in fact, have a “ MENU ” label on the button .

    I truly consider the iPhone Home button icon the single best icon ever. It perfectly represented anything and everything apps could be — it was iconic in every sense of the word.

    ↩︎

  2. It's almost unfathomable how much of a pain in the ass voicemail was before the iPhone. Rather than manage messages on screen, you placed a phone call to your carrier and interfaced with their system by punching number buttons. You had to deal with each message sequentially. “Press 1 to play, 2 to go to the next message, 7 to delete.” And you had to actually listen to the messages to know who they were from.太可怕了。 ↩︎︎

  3. Unless, I suppose, you live in the EU and have exercised your hard-earned right to delete it . ↩︎︎

  4. That's the only way to launch visual intelligence, which means the feature is exclusive to the iPhone 16 lineup and won't be available on iPhone 15 Pros. I'm truly looking forward to this feature, so that's a bummer for iPhone 15 Pro owners. ↩︎︎

  5. Here's Apple's brief documentation for the old Photographic Styles feature (iPhones 13, 14, 15) and the new version (iPhones 16). ↩︎︎

  6. Jet black aluminum is back, and as Vader-esque as it was on the iPhone 7 in 2016, with a new colorway for the Apple Watch Series 10 this year. I have a review unit in jet black on my wrist and it's so great. ↩︎︎

  7. It's fair to argue that Private Cloud Compute is uniquely Apple. Not that Apple is the only company that could build out such an infrastructure for guaranteed-private off-device AI processing, but among the few companies that could do it, Apple is the only one that cares so deeply about privacy that they would. I do not expect Private Cloud Compute to be replicated by Google, Samsung, Meta, Amazon, or Microsoft. Nor any of the AI startups like OpenAI or Anthropic. They simply don't care enough to do it the hard way. Apple does. But that belongs in the marketing for Apple's ongoing Privacy campaign, not for the iPhones 16 in particular. ↩︎︎

entry.content:
Thoughts and Observations in the Wake of Apple's 'It's Glowtime' Keynote

Back in July 2007, I contributed this photo to a Flickr group called, self-describingly, “The Items We Carry”:

17 years later, I've consolidated. 2007 was so long ago that Field Notes hadn't yet been created; my back-pocket notebooks are much slimmer now than that hardcover Moleskine. 1 Instead of the Leatherman and a ring of four keys, I'm down to just two keys and a Halifax key-sized tool from The James Brand. The keys and Halifax lay flat and fit comfortably in the change pocket of a pair of jeans. 2 And while I do own (and very much enjoy ) a Ricoh GR IIIx — a modern but very similarly sized descendant of the above camera — I don't carry it on an everyday basis because iPhone cameras have gotten so good.

But there was an everyday carry item I omitted from the above photo — wired earbuds. I don't remember if I omitted them because I forgot to include them, or if it was for aesthetic reasons. But circa 2007 I generally had a pair of wired Apple earbuds with me. Today, I've always got my AirPods Pro — far and away my favorite consolidation. By weight, AirPods (with case) are heavier, but measured by fussiness, they offer a never-tangled fraction of the wired earbuds experience.

The remaining items in my pockets are equivalent but upgraded. I've got better (and because I no longer wear contact lenses, prescription) sunglasses. I long ago switched from the Pilot G2 to the Zebra Sarasa , a pen I consider nearly perfect. The above Swiss Army watch broke in early 2009, and I've since started a small (I swear) collection of mechanical watches. But on most workdays, there's an Apple Watch on my wrist.

iPhone, AirPods, Apple Watch. I've almost always got two of them with me, and often all three. I'm sure for many of you reading this, it's always all three.

These are Apple's three “everyday carry” products. They're as much a part of our lives as our clothes and glasses and jewelry. They thus go together swimmingly in the same product introduction event.

Last week's “It's Glowtime” event was very strong for Apple. It might have been the single strongest iPhone event since the introduction of the iPhone X. All three platforms are now in excellent, appealing, and coherent shape:

  • iPhone: Last year was a bit “meh” for the non-pro iPhone 15 models, which were stuck with year-old A16 silicon and didn't get the new hardware Action button. This year, the iPhone 16 and 16 Plus get the brand-new A18 chip, the Action button, and the new Camera Control button. That Camera Control button would have made total sense as a Pro-exclusive feature this year (more sense, to me, than making the Action button Pro-exclusive last year) but all new iPhones have it. This year's iPhone 16 and 16 Plus even come in the best and most fun colors in a few years . The iPhone 16 Pro and 16 Pro Max have best-in-class camera systems, the A18 Pro chip (6 GPUs vs. 5 in the regular A18, bigger CPU caches, faster memory and storage I/O), and slightly bigger screens. 3 The iPhone remains the best product in the most important and profitable device category the world has ever seen.

  • Apple Watch: The new Series 10 models sport bigger displays, longer battery life, and 10 percent reductions in thickness and weight. The new watch displays are slightly bigger, and, more importantly, also have noticeably wider viewing angles, and in always-on mode update once per second instead of once per minute. There's an absolutely gorgeous polished jet black option in aluminum — marking, to my taste, the first time in the entire history of Apple Watch that there's a base-priced aluminum model that stands toe-to-toe with the more expensive models on aesthetic grounds 。 But those more expensive models are better than ever too, with Apple replacing polished stainless steel with much lighter polished titanium. I was unaware that titanium could be polished to a mirror-like sheen. Apple had previously made Series models of Apple Watch in titanium — I bought one in Series 5 and again in Series 7 — but those were at the Edition tier, priced above the stainless steel models. There was no Ultra 3 announcement — the lone sour note in the Watch segment — but the Ultra 2 is now available in an excellent and sure-to-be-popular satin black DLC coating .

  • AirPods: No more selling years-old models at entry-level prices. The new good/better/best lineup is clear. Good: new AirPods 4 for $129. Better: AirPods 4 with Active Noise Cancellation (ANC) and a better case (with wireless charging and Find My support, including a speaker) for $179. Best: the existing $249 AirPods Pro, which, yes, debuted two years ago , but which continue to be updated with improved functionality via firmware updates — most notably and importantly now, certified support for use as hearing aids. There's also the revised AirPods Max, with new colors and USB-C replacing Lightning, but alas, no significant internal updates like the H2 chip now available in all other AirPod models, which powers features like voice isolation and nod/shake-your-head Siri interactions or lossless audio support. That's a slightly sour note, but on the whole, the AirPods lineup looks (and sounds) better than ever.

But, still, flying home from California on Tuesday, I was left with a feeling best described as ennui. On Threads, I summarized my feelings with one short sentence :

The obvious truth is that we all, including Apple, miss Steve Jobs.

Quoting me, Walt Mossberg responded :

This👇.绝对正确。 The post-Steve Jobs Apple has been a phenomenal money-making machine and has had a few notable product successes like AirPods and the Apple Watch. But it hasn't replicated the big game changer product experience of the Jobs era.

I've been pondering this for the remainder of the week. One factor is that the iPhone defined the apex of personal computing. In the early years of PCs, everyone knew we wanted portability. Most of us — including me — thought we reached that with laptops. But laptops don't go with us everywhere, and, it turns out, we want computers that go with us everywhere. That's the iPhone, and the original iPhone in 2007 established the all-touch-screen form factor and general concept right out of the gate. That first iPhone blew our minds the moment Steve Jobs showed it to us.

Eventually, some company will introduce such a product again. It might be Apple. If it happens any time soon or soon-ish, it probably will be Apple. Apple, as a company, has a long-term strategy that it hopes will make it as likely as possible that it will be Apple. But there's been no such product since the iPhone and, in my opinion, there is no technology extant today that would enable such a product. I feel confident that if Steve Jobs were alive and still leading Apple product development, there would have been no iPhone-like mind-blown-the-moment-you-first-saw-it new product in the intervening years.

Mossberg correctly cites AirPods and Apple Watches as big successes of the post-Jobs era. Not coincidentally, they are two of the three platforms Apple featured in last week's event — and two of the three that people carry wherever they go. But we don't really carry AirPods and Apple Watch — we wear them. They're not more important than our iPhones, but they are more intimate, more personal.

But they're also more subtle. When AirPods debuted many people thought they looked weird to wear. When Apple Watch debuted people were underwhelmed. But it turns out, perhaps even more so than with the iPhone, Apple nailed the design with both products right out of the gate. Apple Watch has an iconic, instantly recognizable form factor, but from a distance of more than a few feet away, it'd be hard to tell a brand-new Series 10 from 2015's original “Series 0” models. The original watch straps remain compatible with the newest models — including even the Ultras. With AirPods, the stems have gotten noticeably shorter, but on the whole, they're the exact same basic concept as the original models from 2016 . They're even offered in the exact same array of colors: white, white, or white.

What we're seeing is Tim Cook's Apple. Cook is a strong, sage leader, and the proof is that the entire company is now ever more in his image. That's inevitable. It's also not at all to say Apple is worse off. In some ways it is, but in others, Apple is far better. I can't prove any of this, of course, but my gut says that a Steve-Jobs–led Apple today would be noticeably less financially successful and industry-dominating than the actual Tim-Cook–led Apple has been.

I think Apple Watch, under Jobs, would have been more like iPod was or AirPods have been: a product entirely defined by Apple, not a platform for third-party developers. (Jobs was famously reluctant to even make iPhone a platform.)

But the biggest difference is that Apple, under Jobs, was quirky , and I think would have remained noticeably more quirky than it has been under Cook. You'd be wrong, I say, to argue that Cook has drained the fun out of Apple. But I do think he's eliminated quirkiness. Cook's Apple takes too few risks. Jobs's Apple took too many risks.

Tim Cook is no mere bean counter.远非如此。 He shares with Jobs a driving ambition to change the world. Cook, just like Jobs, surely relates deeply to this quip from Walt Disney: “We don't make movies to make money. We make money to make more movies.” But the ways Cook is driven to change the world are different.

Jobs often wore his heart on his shirtsleeve, not merely in public but on stage. Remember the 2010 WWDC keynote, when Jobs had an iPhone demo fail because the Wi-Fi wasn't working, and 20 minutes later he came back on stage and angrily demanded that the media turn off their portable Wi-Fi base stations being used for live-blogging the keynote? He was fucking angry and he let us know it. You simply didn't mess with a Steve Jobs keynote.

Cook almost never reveals his true passionate self in public. But at least one time he did. At the 2014 annual shareholders meeting, Cook faced a question from a representative of the right-wing National Center for Public Policy Research (NCPPR). As reported by Bryan Chaffin at The Mac Observer :

During the question and answer session, however, the NCPPR representative asked Mr. Cook two questions, both of which were in line with the principles espoused in the group's proposal. The first question challenged an assertion from Mr. Cook that Apple's sustainability programs and goals — Apple plans on having 100 percent of its power come from green sources — are good for the bottom line.

The representative asked Mr. Cook if that was the case only because of government subsidies on green energy. Mr. Cook didn't directly answer that question, but instead focused on the second question: the NCPPR representative asked Mr. Cook to commit right then and there to doing only those things that were profitable.

What ensued was the only time I can recall seeing Tim Cook angry, and he categorically rejected the worldview behind the NCPPR's advocacy. He said that there are many things Apple does because they are right and just, and that a return on investment (ROI) was not the primary consideration on such issues.

“When we work on making our devices accessible by the blind,” he said, “I don't consider the bloody ROI.” He said the same thing about environmental issues, worker safety, and other areas where Apple is a leader.

As evidenced by the use of “bloody” in his response — the closest thing to public profanity I've ever seen from Mr. Cook — it was clear that he was quite angry. His body language changed, his face contracted, and he spoke in rapid fire sentences compared to the usual metered and controlled way he speaks.

He didn't stop there, however, as he looked directly at the NCPPR representative and said, “If you want me to do things only for ROI reasons, you should get out of this stock.”

A philosophy of “Whatever is best for the ROI” is McKinsey-flavored cowardice, not leadership. Sometimes a leader needs to make decisions with uncertain business sense, or even knowing that the decision doesn't make business sense, but simply because their intuition or conscience tell them it's the right thing to do. Insofar as he's willing to make such decisions, Cook is like Jobs. But what sort of decisions those are, are very different.

Jobs was driven to improve the way computers work. Cook is driven to improve the way humans live. Accessibility and the environment are much higher priorities under Cook than they were under Jobs. Apple's entire foray into Health has occurred under Cook's leadership — and Health-related features were tentpole features in last week's keynote. I wouldn't be surprised if it cost far more money to get AirPods Pro certified as medical-grade hearing aids than Apple will make back in profits from an increase in sales. The Apple 2030 initiative to bring the company's entire carbon footprint to net zero emissions is fundamentally about doing the right thing, not just selling more products.

Jobs emphasized making more interesting products, and maximizing surprise and delight upon their unveilings. Tim Cook wouldn't have sent the police after Gizmodo's purloined iPhone 4 prototype ; Steve Jobs probably thought Apple took it easy on them.

Cook values predictability. But predictability is in conflict with quirkiness. You don't need to even recognize Mark Gurman's name to have predicted that last week's event would focus on new iPhones, new AirPods, and new Apple Watches. Nor do you need to follow the rumor mill to have correctly guessed that all of those new products would look very similar to the models that preceded them. Evolve, evolve, evolve. There's no resting on laurels inside Apple with any of those products. The iPhones 16, Apple Watch Series 10, and AirPods 4 are all the result of intensely-focused industry-leading engineering (including in fields like material engineering) and design. But they also all basically look exactly like all of us expected them to look.

Remember the 3rd-gen iPod Nano in 2007? Aka “ the fat Nano ”:

It's quite possible you don't remember the fat Nano, because it wasn't insanely great, even though it replaced 2nd-gen iPod Nano models that were. And so a year later, with the 4th-gen Nanos , Apple went back to the tall-and-skinny design, as though the fat Nano had never happened.

That fat Nano was quirky. It was also, in hindsight, obviously a mistake. I'm quite sure that inside Apple there were designers and product people who thought it was a mistake before it shipped. Steve Jobs shipped it anyway, surely because his gut told him it was the right thing to try. Tim Cook's Apple doesn't make mistakes like that. That's ultimately why Cook's Apple is more successful — with more customers, more revenue, higher margins (and thus more profit), and more, well, sheer dominance (and, thus, more regulatory scrutiny). But it's also why Cook's Apple delivers fewer surprises. The delight is still there, but there's less amazement. It's by design. They're not trying but failing to reach the heights of the Jobs era's ecstatic design novelty, because those peaks had accompanying valleys. Apple today is aiming for, and achieving, utterly consistent excellence. Quirkiness no longer fits.

The lampshade iMac G4 . The G4 Cube . Peripherals like the iSight camera — a product that was never intended to sell in massive numbers, but belongs in a museum alongside the best designs from Dieter Rams's Braun. Flower Power and Dalmatian iMacs . Under Jobs, Apple made many products that were memorable at each, or at least every other, revised generation. But sometimes — like the fat Nano — they were memorable for being duds. Under Cook, Apple produces instantly iconic designs that tend only to evolve — in mostly predictable ways, on mostly predictable schedules. 4

Tim Cook's Apple has not missed any fundamental new technology or shift that would have resulted in industry-changing new products or platforms that, if he'd lived, Steve Jobs would have led Apple to create through his singular genius or sheer force of will. But I also don't think we'd have been left with new iPhones 16 that look like last year's iPhones 15, which looked like the iPhones 14, which looked like the iPhones 13, which looked like the iPhones 12, which looked like the iPhones 11 except that year the side rails went from rounded back to flat, like the iPhone 4 and 5 models. I can show you an iPhone 4 and you'll know, instantly, that it is either an iPhone 4 or 4S. I can show you an iPhone 5 and you'll know it's either an iPhone 5 or 5S (or the first iPhone SE ). If it were a black-and-slate iPhone 5 you might even know it's a 5 specifically, not a 5S, because the anodization of the black iPhone 5 wore off over time, producing a weathered look — a patina — that I found endearing in an evocative way no subsequent iPhone has. It was an imperfection, but sometimes imperfections are what we love most about products. 5 Show me an iPhone from 2020–2024 a decade from now and I'll have to remember exactly when the Action button and Camera Control appeared to know which was which.

Cook has patience where Jobs would grow restless. In the Jobs era, when a keynote ended, we'd sometimes turn to each other and say, “Can you believe ____?” No one asked that after last week's keynote. Much of what Apple announced was impressive. Very little was disappointing. Nothing was hard to believe or surprising.

This isn't bad for Apple, or a sign of institutional decline. If anything, under Cook, Apple more consistently achieves near-perfection. Tolerances are tighter. Ship dates seldom slip. But it's a change that makes the company less fun to keenly observe and obsess over. Cook's Apple is not overly cautious, but it's never reckless. Jobs's Apple was occasionally reckless, for better and worse .

My dissatisfaction flying home from last week's event is, ultimately, selfish. I miss having my mind blown. I miss being utterly surprised. I miss occasionally being disappointed by a product design that stretched quirky all the way to wacky . I miss being amazed by something entirely unexpected out of left field. Poor me, stuck only with the announcement of noticeably improved versions of three products — three product families — that zillions of people around the world, myself included, carry with us wherever we go.

  1. Moleskine has long made thin, vaguely Field-Notes-y “ Cahier ” notebooks, but they suck. After just a few days in my back pocket, pages would start falling out. Field Notes aren't just fun; they are meant to be used and abused . ↩︎︎

  2. Also known as the iPod Nano pocket . ↩︎︎

  3. The overall devices are now, once again, slightly larger with the 16 Pro and Pro Max, too — which is not a positive for fans of smaller iPhones. iPhone 12/13 Mini holdouts, this footnote is for you. ↩︎︎

  4. I also believe that Apple would have gone back to live-on-stage keynotes, post-COVID, if Jobs were still around. The differences between those two keynote formats — live stage events vs. pre-filmed movies — are a good proxy for the changes to Apple as a whole. Apple's modern pre-filmed keynotes are better for the company and better for most people who want to watch them. (Viewership numbers, I am reliably told, are higher than ever — and today dwarf the viewership of Jobs-era keynotes.) They're far more interesting visually and more information-dense. (No need to wait for new presenters to walk on stage and then off again. Just cut to a new scene.) They're more expensive to produce but the results are 100 percent predictable. No Apple keynote demo will ever fail again. But they're also less exciting. Demo fails are fun (from the audience, not from the stage) and — as noted above, w/r/t the Wi-Fi at WWDC 2010 — memorable. And the possibility that any live demo might fail adds a degree of palpable tension to every demo, even the ones that wind up going off without a hitch . It's like the difference between watching a live motorcycle stunt show and a Fast and Furious movie. The movie looks better, but carries no sense of actual danger. ↩︎︎

  5. Or people. ↩︎︎

There's a scene in Martin Scorsese's Casino . Gangster Nicky Santoro (Joe Pesci) and two of his goon friends are in a nightclub in the Tangiers casino resort (a fictionalized version of the old Stardust), which is run by Ace Rothstein (Robert De Niro). Santoro and Rothstein, who'd been friends for decades, are now on the outs. The Tangiers is a front for the mafia and the Teamsters. Rothstein, a gambling genius who was born to run a casino, is earning major bank for the bosses back home. Santoro is gangstering up Las Vegas, and is under severe law enforcement scrutiny. They just held a contentious meeting, just the two of them, at Santoro's request, in the middle of the desert — a meeting Rothstein wasn't sure wouldn't conclude with him dead in a freshly dug hole in the sand.

Santoro and his two friends are just a threesome.都是男人。 Morose.

Rothstein comes in with Billy Sherbert (Don Rickles) and a party of half a dozen or so men and women, including Oscar Goodman, famed defense attorney and future mayor of Las Vegas (playing himself), and several women. Everyone (but Rothstein, who's not much for fun) is laughing. You'd be laughing too if you were out having drinks with Don Fucking Rickles and Oscar Goodman.

Santoro gripes about Rothstein not acknowledging him, and, well, makes some comments that suggest he doesn't hold Jews in the highest esteem. Santoro's right-hand man, Frank Marino (played by the great Frank Vincent, of Billy “Go Get Your Fucking Shine Box” Batts fame), dryly observes, “They're having a good time, too.”

The camera pulls back to show their threesome, alone in their booth, isolated. Santoro, who is absolutely not having a good time, replies, “So are we.”

I've been thinking about that scene a lot, lately.

Allison Johnson, in a piece for The Verge headlined “ European iPhones Are More Fun Now ”:

Whining about stuff is a treasured American pastime, so allow me to indulge: the iPhone is more fun in Europe now, and it's not fair.

They're getting all kinds of stuff because they have cool regulators, not, like, regular regulators. Third-party app stores , the ability for browsers to run their own engines , Fortnite , and now the ability toreplace lots of default apps ? I want it, too! Imagine if Chrome on iOS wasn't just a rinky dink little Safari emulator!

Imagine if Chrome could deplete your iPhone battery as fast as it does your MacBook battery. Imagine if you were one of the millions (zillions?) of people whose “incognito mode” browsing history was observed and stored by Google and deletedonly after they lost a lawsuit . Imagine — and this takes a lot of imagination — if Google actually shipped a version of Chrome for iOS, only for the EU, that used its own battery-eating rendering engine instead of using the energy-efficient system version of WebKit.

Imagine downloading a new dialer app with a soundboard of fart sounds and setting it as your default! Unfortunately, Apple doesn't seem interested in sharing these possibilities with everyone.

听起来很有趣。

Sure, we've got retro game emulators in the app store . And that rules. But that's only because Apple was worried everyone in the EU was about to download AltStore PAL so they could play Ocarina of Time on their iPhones.

If the benefit of the DMA is allowing emulators worldwide how is that an advantage for people in the EU?

Here's the thing: wouldn't it just be good business to offer everyone the same choices no matter where they live? It's not as if Apple was making two different iPhones to try to appeal to different cultural preferences. It's making one iPhone that's more flexible and customizable and one that isn't.

Maybe, bit by bit, Apple will cave in and offer parity the way it did with emulators. But I think the company should make an uncharacteristic move: drop the charade and let everyone, everywhere have the same iPhone. It would be bold! Courageous, even! But most importantly, it would be a lot more fun.

Yes, let's allow everyone, around the world, to delete their Camera app .听起来很有趣。

Federico Viticci, on Threads :

My realization in 2024 has been that the DMA fork of iOS is the best iPhone experience. We can finally use our phones like actual computers with more default apps and apps from external sources.

And on MacStories :

It's still iOS, with the tasteful design, vibrant app ecosystem, high-performance animations, and accessibility we've come to expect from Apple; at the same time, it's a more flexible and fun version of iOS predicated upon the assumption that users deserve options to control more aspects of how their expensive pocket computers should work. Or, as I put it : some of the flexibility of Android, but on iOS, sounds like a dream to me.

Apparently, this thought — that people who demand options should have them — really annoys a lot of (generally American) pundits who seemingly consider the European Commission a draconian entity that demands changes out of spite for a particular corporation, rather than a group of elected officials who regulate based on what they believe is best for their constituents and the European market.

Let's run a tally. On the EU side, there is Fortnite and other games from Epic, a shady company that was justifiably booted from the App Store for bait-and-switch chicanery intended to provoke a lawsuit in which they got their asses handed back to them . On the rest-of-the-world side we have the imminent release of iPhone Mirroring and Apple Intelligence. I don't play Fortnite, and even if I did, I wouldn't on my phone, but I find the latter far more interesting — and fun — than the former.

The non-Epic iOS software available exclusively in the EU is ... well, nothing of interest. Maybe some apps that help with content piracy. Other than that, nothing. Admittedly, the DMA only went into effect 6 months ago. Long-term, maybe there will arise a thriving ecosystem of useful and fun apps and games that are exclusively available in EU marketplaces. Right now, it's Fortnite. There are a bunch of articles (and surely soon to be more) informing EU citizens how to access Apple Intelligence (by lying about where they are). There are crickets chirping regarding how iOS users outside the EU can cheat their way into the EU's new DMA rules.没有人关心。

Meanwhile no one in the EU will get Apple Intelligence or iPhone Mirroring, both of which features are very useful, and, dare I say, quite fun. Should we judge how much fun each side of the continental divide is having by how much fun they theoretically could be having, or by how much fun they are having?

As it stands, the fun side is not the EU. But hope springs eternal.
